fields.description:
The Jelly docs at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Jelly+Tags#JellyTags-BetaTags suggest that removeProject takes a pId parameter (notice the weird mixed caseness). However when you actually submit:

{code}
<JiraJelly xmlns:jira="jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.JiraTagLib">
<jira:RemoveProject pId="10000" />
</JiraJelly>
{code}

You get an error back from JIRA:

{code}
 <JiraJelly xmlns:jira='jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.JiraTagLib'>
  <Error action='DeleteProject'>
    <TagContents>(RemoveProject(pId=10000))</TagContents>
    <ExecutedAs>user=admin</ExecutedAs>
    <ErrorMessage>Tag RemoveProject requires (jelly.username, jelly.project.id) variables to be set in the Context</ErrorMessage>
  </Error>
</JiraJelly> 
{code}

The problem is that RemoveProject extends ProjectAwareActionTagSupport. This means username and projectid are expected to be "in the context". The project is never being put in the context. I'm not positive but I think this normally happens via preContextValidation which RemoveProject doesn't override.

This code was originally checked in in 2003 (with no tests) and I have doubts that it ever worked. No one has ever complained until now which gives an indication of how little use Jelly gets.
fields.summary: Jelly's removeProject is broken and probably never worked

fields.description:
If I set the window to 900 pixels wide and then display an issue, the window as a whole gets a horizontal scroll bar.  But if I scroll down to the Activities section (and click on "All"), each individual activity has its own scroll bar.

This is Bad Design:  In general, any scrolling area inside another scrolling area is hard to read and does not use the limited screen space well.  In particular, the Activity items seem to be limited to about 3/4 of the available screen width, despite that the 1/4 of the width remaining on the right has nothing in it.
fields.summary: Narrow window in issue display causes each Activity item to have separate horizontal scroll bar

fields.description: In the view issue screen, when trying to select the title of the issue (for copying/pasting), I can't select just the name; I'm forced to select the whole header bar.
fields.summary: Can't select issue summary in issue view screen

fields.description:
A sub-task has a mandatory type of "sub-task".
It is impossible to assign a different type from those available.
Intuitively, a sub-task is defined as such because it has a parent issue, and not because it is of a certain type!
There are plenty of legitimate cases where you want to assign a specific type to a sub-task.

Is it possible to plan an evolution where we could change the type of sub-tasks?
A sub-task might rather be seen as a specific "built-in" type of link between the parent issue and the child?
fields.summary: Subtask issue type

fields.description:
I've been thinking about this for awhile now:
System fields are just a pain in the butt. 
Custom fields are genius.  

1. From a development standpoint every system field has to be treated as its own little animal while custom fields can (except for the pesky cascading select) be treated abstractly.  

2. All the System fields have nearly duplicate analogs in the Custom Field world:
Description=Text Area Field
Summary=Text Field
Fix/Affects Version = Multi Version Field
DueDate = Date Custom Field
etc.

3. The system fields always show up on the simple search page regardless of whether they're visible in any projects.

4. Custom fields have great tools for setting up contexts based on project and type while system fields don't.

How about just getting rid of System fields forever?
fields.summary: Get rid of system fields

	at com.atlassian.jira.permission.DefaultPermissionSchemeManager.deleteEntity(DefaultPermissionSchemeManager.java:217)
{code}

JIRA should be more graceful and inform the user the permission object he is trying to delete has already been removed, instead of showing an exception page.
fields.summary: Deleting the same permission object twice in a permission scheme throws an exception

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21160].
  {panel}

I've commented on http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Starting+JIRA+Standalone+automatically+on+Linux which includes the jira.smf manifest I am using to start and stop JIRA automatically on OpenSolaris.

As the note states I've hacked this together with no real knowledge of what I am doing.
It appears to work fine on my machine so far.

A copy of the comment is included here as well:

{code:language=xml|title=jira.smf}<?xml version="1.0"?>
<!DOCTYPE service_bundle SYSTEM "/usr/share/lib/xml/dtd/service_bundle.dtd.1">
<!--
  Assumes dependency on svc:/network/cswmysql5:default

  Assumes user=jira group=other
  Assumes :home is where your JIRA instance is installed.
  Assumes :home/bin has symlinks to the actual version you are running.
-->

<service_bundle type='manifest' name='JIRA'>

  <service
    name='network/jira'
    type='service'
    version='1'>

    <create_default_instance enabled='false' />
    <single_instance />

    <!--
       Wait for network interfaces to be initialized.
    -->
    <dependency name='network'
        grouping='require_all'
        restart_on='error'
        type='service'>
        <service_fmri value='svc:/milestone/network:default'/>
    </dependency>

    <!--
       Wait for all local filesystems to be mounted.
    -->
    <dependency name='filesystem-local'
        grouping='require_all'
        restart_on='none'
        type='service'>
        <service_fmri
            value='svc:/system/filesystem/local:default'/>
    </dependency>

    <!--
       Wait for mysql
    -->
    <dependency name='mysql'
        grouping='require_all'
        restart_on='none'
        type='service'>
        <service_fmri
            value='svc:/network/cswmysql5:default'/>
    </dependency>

    <!-- execute as user jira -->
    <method_context>
        <method_credential user='jira' group='other' />
    </method_context>

    <exec_method
        type='method'
        name='start'
        exec='./bin/startup.sh'
        timeout_seconds='60'>
    </exec_method>

    <exec_method
        type='method'
        name='stop'
        exec='./bin/shutdown.sh'
        timeout_seconds='15'>
    </exec_method>

    <template>
       <common_name>
          <loctext xml:lang='C'>JIRA</loctext>
       </common_name>
       <documentation>
          <doc_link name='jira'
                    uri='http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/' />
       </documentation>
    </template>

  </service>

</service_bundle>{code}
fields.summary: Supply smf manifest for installing JIRA as a service for OpenSolaris

fields.description:
permgen.sh on fails to guess a JAVA_HOME correctly.

On my installation it is installed the Java binary is symlinked into /usr/bin/java
with the jdk in /usr/java

I added the following after the apple guess section of permgen.sh:
{noformat}
# OpenSolaris test to guess a JAVA_HOME
if [ -z "$JAVA_HOME" -a -z "$JRE_HOME" ]; then
  if [ -f /usr/bin/java ]; then
    JAVA_HOME="/usr"
  fi
fi
{noformat}
fields.summary: PermGen memory not set, if JAVA_HOME is set incorrectly or missing

fields.description:
all the issues you mentioned were indeed moved from Marketing (Core) to Channel Marketing. For our Marketing department we started with one project, which quickly became insufficient. So we created additional projects and some of the - by that time "core" project - issues were moved to one of the new projects.

The common denominator:

    * all of these issues are sub-tasks

This results in, for instance, a messed up pie chart gadget because the stats don't come out right.

fields.description:
A deleteProject SOAP call may try to delete an issue more than one time causing it to fail with an Exception.

The SOAP deleteProject call gets all issues for the given project through the OfbizDelegator, and then calls on a deleteIssue back-end action which deletes the Issue and its sub-tasks amongst other things.

Now, if a parent issue is placed before any of its sub-tasks in the list gotten by the OfBizDelegator, the deleteProject call will try to delete the subtask(s) twice. 

The first time implicitly by calling the deleteIssue back-end action on the parent (which will delete the sub-tasks associated with this parent issue), and the second time by trying to delete the sub-task explicitly because it is in the list of issues to be deleted, but this will fail because that sub-task has already been deleted.

The failure will be in lines 446-447 when it tries to verify permissions on the Project this issue belongs to and the project will be null because the issue is null too (it doesn't exist anymore). Therefore, the if on line 447 will become true (project == null), and we will get a RemotePermissionException saying "The project specified does not exist or you don't have permission to delete issues in it."

The stack trace will look like:

Exception in thread "main" AxisFault
 faultCode: {http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/}Server.userException
 faultSubcode: 
 faultString: com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemoteException: Error removing project: TEST-PROJECT-KEYCaused by com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemoteException: Error removing issues: com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemotePermissionException: This issue does not exist or you don't have permission to view it.Caused by com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemotePermissionException: This issue does not exist or you don't have permission to view it.
	at com.atlassian.jira.rpc.soap.service.IssueServiceImpl.retrieveIssue(IssueServiceImpl.java:889)
	at com.atlassian.jira.rpc.soap.service.IssueServiceImpl.getIssue(IssueServiceImpl.java:150)
	at com.atlassian.jira.rpc.soap.service.IssueServiceImpl.deleteIssue(IssueServiceImpl.java:446)
	at com.atlassian.jira.rpc.soap.service.ProjectServiceImpl.deleteProject(ProjectServiceImpl.java:490)
	at com.atlassian.jira.rpc.soap.JiraSoapServiceImpl.deleteProject(JiraSoapServiceImpl.java:405)
fields.summary: Soap deleteProject call may try to delete an issue more than one time causing it to fail with an Exception

fields.description:
The idea is to have a specific atlassian-jira-security.log that contains important events such as user logged in, logged out, session created and so on.

This would allow for more specific information about how is logged into JIRA and when.  

This has been mooted for a while and is now being done in response to the Atlassian security incident.
fields.summary: Put a new security log into JIRA so that important events can be specifically logged

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21146].
  {panel}

The error message is a generic one:
Changing the attachment, index, backup or restore settings is not allowed for security reasons. You must edit jira-application.properties and explicitly set 'jira.paths.set.allowed=true'. Restart JIRA and then the path settings will be able to be changed.

It's hard to understand because you're not trying to change settings right there, you're trying to restore an XML backup. 

It should be something easier to understand, like:
Restoring from an XML backup requires a configuration change. You must edit jira-application.properties and explicitly set 'jira.paths.set.allowed=true'. Restart JIRA and then the path settings will be able to be changed. See <insert doc link> for a discussion on security.
fields.summary: Restore from backup warning about absolute paths should be a better description, like 'You must configure JIRA to allow XML restore...'

fields.description:
If one starts to add a comment to an issue, and the window is narrower than the minimum screen width (see issue JIRA-21115), then the text entry box for the comment is the minimum screen width.  But the box cannot be scrolled -- the horizontal scroll bar applies to the body of the issue, but not the frame containing the comment entry box.

(This seems to be another version of "somebody is being *way* too clever with screen manipulation".  Can't we go back to the previous screen layout which worked simply and easily and like every other web page in the universe?)
fields.summary: When adding comment, if window is narrow, the comment entry box is wider than the window and cannot be scrolled horizontally
Add checking for orphaned versions to the integrity checker...

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21118].
  {panel}

Hi Rosie,
 
I am introducing my employer to JIRA for the first time so have become the JIRA administrator by default. I have a good idea of what I'd like the system to do but would like a bit more reference/procedural material to help me set it up correctly from the start.
 
The page http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/EHOSTING/JIRA+Hosted+101 is superb - I love how you've made it possible to scan down the page using expandable links and I think the "Why would I do this?" question is a fantastic device! 
 
My request is for more information (though not necessarily for hosted services customers only):
 
1. General recommendations for setup - Include an overall workflow for new customers. Perhaps a flow diagram as well?
what you need to do and in what order. i.e. create project first, adopt or redesign issues? add users first? design project roles first?  What not to do before another task.
 
2. Personally, I have to set up this situation on a hosted system so I was looking for some more complex scenario documentation than that currently available.

    *
      e.g. For example when allocating 6 users to 3 different projects but giving them different roles in each project. Some users work in all three, some in just two. Two projects need to allow cross-project linking.
    *
      My PM wants to be able to export some issue data to export into another database - what do I need to do to facilitate this?

 
3. What are schemes really designed for? What should I watch out for when setting one up? Why does the system display both the default and the customised scheme within a given project?
 
4. Give a breakdown of a small part of a workflow and explain a typical design - what's mandatory, purpose is served by a transition,   
 
5. If I delete a default issue etc, how can I retrieve it?
 
6. The whole area of the default settings and how they can be customised is a bit confused especially as a given project is displayed as using a "default..." as well as a  ".<customised> scheme". I cannot distinguish which settings are coming from each source and would like to understand how the customised bits work... superimposed over template default?  how the default plays into a project nevertheless?. 
 
   default groups needs more clarification - for example:

    *
      a detailed table about what each of the default groups can do.
    *
      for instance why don't my new users receive a username/password email?
    *
      When I click jira-developers in the default browser, I see that there are "no permisssions/notifications/issue security or saved filters associated with this group"  yet members of that group do receive notifications. How is that explained?
    *
      what are the advantages of setting up my own groups and what should I watch out for

 
Hope this makes sense.
 
Having said that, I think JIRA is remarkably well designed. It has such a great, simple and consistent interface. And it's got extensive help! - I love the fact I can communicate feedback to the author! 
But am trying to get the hang of organising the system to suit our needs and struggling a bit.
 
Thanks, Celia

Bug tracking and project tracking for software development powered by Atlassian JIRA  (v4.1.1#522) | Report a problem  | Request a feature  | Contact administrators

Jira 4.1.1 generates issue screens with very wide minimum widths.  Using JRA-4482 as an example, when I set the window to 1000 pixels wide, it still demands horizontal scrolling.  This is a much larger minimum-page-width than the previous version of Jira I used.

fields.description:
The Issue Navigator displays results grouped by Project regardless of what column the filter results are ordered by. 

When the results of a filter are set to be ordered by fixVersions they are but only on a group by group basis. The groups being each individual Project.

To make the problem even more interesting is the fact that this grouping only applies to issues that actually have a fixVersion set. Issues that do not have a fixVersion set are then listed in what appears to be no apparent order. 

This is the case in both v3.13.5 and v4.0.2.

We are trying to create a filter that selects issues across all JIRA Projects that have a custom field set to a specific value and then order them by fixVersion.

The JQL for this filter is:
"Business Initiative" = "Production Committee" ORDER BY fixVersion ASC

You will see the first two pages of the results in the two attached screen shots.

Screen shot #1 shows issues that have a fixVersion value set. They are obviously not sorted strictly by the fixVersion field. In actuality they are sorted first by Project Key prefix and then by fixVersions.

Screen shot #2 shows issues that do not have a fixVersion value set. These are obviously NOT being sorted first by the Project Key prefix.

This bug in effect means that sorting by any field other than Key cannot be achieved!
fields.summary: Issue Navigator does not sort properly by any column other than Key

fields.description:
DB indices should be added to the non-xml upgrade path.

What was previously known as the "[Alternative method of upgrading JIRA|http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/TIHGD]" refers to starting a new instance of JIRA while configured to use a database from an older version of JIRA. This is necessary for large instances of JIRA. This issue prescribes an automated way to upgrade the db indices which should make primary this method of upgrading JIRA .
fields.summary: Add Database index upgrade job when using in-place upgrade method

However, this plugin only provides limited features, as in:
# *Have to manually provide the recipient email & issue info* - Whenever you click on email-this-issue a new page opens. Then we have to copy&paste the mail address from the issue description, fill in a subject and write the body.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21101].
  {panel}

A clickjacking attack on JIRA would most likely take the form of a third-party site, containing an invisible iframe on top of an unrelated page. The iframe would contain a page in JIRA. The victim would believe he was clicking on the other site but would actually be clicking in JIRA and performing actions he didn't intend.

It enables attackers to perform many actions in our apps, provided that:
    * The victim has an active session or "remember me" is set, and
    * The victim can be tricked into clicking or typing into an innocent-looking page element on a third-party site.

It requires no XSS vulnerability in JIRA in order to exploit.

Twitter's solution to this was to include a line of JavaScript at the top of every page to break out of frames. This might not work as a broad-scale solution for us (GreenHopper and gadgets both use iframes legitimately) but could be used for administration pages at least.

This threat could be partially mitigated by requiring two clicks for any major administration action. e.g. Currently you can go directly to the project deletion confirmation page and delete a project in one click. If the confirmation page was also XSRF-protected (not just the deletion action itself), it would behave the same for an end-user but would be harder for an attacker to exploit.

-----------

Example attack: This button on some random website gives no indication of malice:

!Clickjack1.png!

But clicking on it actually deletes a project in JIRA:

!Clickjack2.png!

The example HTML for this attack is attached; just insert the ID of the project you want to delete into the iframe URL, and use with caution!
fields.summary: JIRA is vulnerable to clickjacking attacks

fields.description:

And using up/down triangles is not consistent with other UI concepts in JIRA 4.1 like switching through different versions of a project or paging in issue navigator. 

The down triangle is used in JIRA for drop down menues.

I would prefere something like this

!gui mockup with left_right arrows.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "Next/previous issue" on view issue should use left/right arrows instead of up/down

fields.description:
Renaming a verion's name will break all filters that use it:
1. Create a Version in JIRA Project
2. Create 2 issues and add these to this Version.
3. Then create a Filter referenced to this Version
4. The 2 Tickets should appear
5. Add the gadget on the dashboard Show Filter with this Filter.
5. Now go to the Version Manager and rename the Version.
6. Go back to the Dashboard and find that the Gadget has an Error referenced to the Versions ID.

Looking at the filter's JQL it is specifying it by name and not its ID
fields.summary: Improve JQL to follow Version ID instead of Version name

fields.description:
Through the lifecycle of a issue it can be necessary to move the issue to another projects, which actually results in a new issue key because the project key is part of it.

This is a nightmare for all systems which have to be integrated/connected to Jira and have a reference on the issue key. As one example, commits made in an version control system (like subversion) contain the old issue key and loose their reference if the issue is moved to another project.

Therefore the issue key should be a unique identifier which is never chnged after creation.
fields.summary: Use unique and project independent issue key

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21067].
{panel}
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 7 September 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

We're excited to announce that we've added support for 25 new programming languages in the code macro and it is now available in JIRA Software 7.5 starting from today!
We really appreciate your patience with this feature request.

Now the code macro supports the following languages:
 * Actionscript
 * Ada
 * Applescript
 * Bash
 * C
 * C#
 * C++
 * CSS (Less, Sass)
 * Erlang
 * Go
 * Groovy
 * Haskell
 * HTML
 * Java
 * Javascript
 * Lua
 * Objective-C
 * Perl
 * Php
 * Python
 * R
 * Nyan
 * Ruby
 * Scala
 * Sql (but like [lots more keywords|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-renderer/pull-requests/21/jsds-337-update-code-macro/diff#chg-src/main/java/com/atlassian/renderer/v2/macro/code/formatter/SqlFormatter.java])
 * Swift
 * Visual Basic
 * XML
 * Yaml

As we've mentioned before, our Cloud and Server deployment options are now on separate roadmaps ([read more here|https://www.atlassian.com/blog/announcements/prioritizing-roadmaps-cloud-server-data-center]), but this is a great example of a new feature shipped in cloud, that was popular and prioritized with server customers, that we have brought into server.

JIRA Software 7.5 is now available to [download|https://atlassian.com/software/jira/download] so you can start planning your upgrade straight away!

Cheers,
Jakub Lazinski
Product Manager, JIRA Server
{panel}
Support for the C, C++, C#, and Visual Basic languages would be particularly useful.
fields.summary: Support for More Languages via the {code} macro

fields.summary: JIRA Activity Servlet throws stacktrace when project has been deleted - StreamsActivityServlet Error getting activity java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: The Project argument and its backing generic value must not be null
Have option to display overdue issues in red for the Filter Results gadget

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21047].
  {panel}

Have Any restrictions on the use of specific symbols defining the radio button type field Values, such as <> "", () -?

I have a problem finding by the radio button type field values, which is used double quotes - ""
Error that no such values

Steps to replicate:

1. create radio button field:
TEST_FIELD
2. add values to this radio button field:

value 1
"value 2"
"value 3"
3. Create issue with custom field values 
(one issue with value TEST_FIELD=value 1
one issue with value TEST_FIELD="value 2")

4. Simple search for issues by the field values TEST_FIELD="value 2"

received an error message that is incorrect search query

Currently the only way to extract this information is by using the advanced query in JIRA 4+:

TEST_FIELD = "\"value 2\""

Is there a way to escape the quotes in simple search?
fields.summary: Simple search doesn't handle quotes

fields.description:
In the issue navigator, when clicking on "Views", choosing XML (RSS) under Safari 4.0.5 we get :
Safari can't open the page "feed://jira.fr.euro.apple.com:8090/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-rss/temp/SearchRequest.xml?jqlQuery=project+%3D+BE+AND+status+%3D+Open+ORDER+BY+priority+DESC&tempMax=1000" because Safari can't load any data from this location.
fields.summary: Views RSS feed under Safari doesn't work.
JIRA RSS wraps email with <a> tag

fields.description: When I change the "Link Color" and "Link Active Color" under the Administration Look And Feel section, the Dashboard does not change to match.
fields.summary: Dashboard does not obey link "Look and feel" options

fields.description:
When you have a lot of gadgets (about 20-30) on a single dashboard, when loading the dashboard some of them won't fully load and get stuck on the "loading" bar image.

I have only been able to reproduce it in Firefox, but not Chrome or IE.

It appears to happen when the front page takes a long time to load during the rendering. 

Occasionally all gadgets will load, but sometimes a few won't load at random.

This did not happen on Jira 4.0.1
fields.summary: Some gadgets fail to load when you have a lot of them.

fields.description:
The date time picker's interface and return value in the Hungarian local should be *DE/DU* instead of *AM/PM* respectively.
An error occurs when editing fields of this type as *AM/PM* is not allowed. Other locales seem to be fine.
fields.summary: Date Time Picker AM/PM values in Hungarian local should display and return DE/DU

fields.description:
We have added an upgrade task to set jira.maximum.authentication.attempts.allowed=5 on all instances even if they previous had set it to something else.

This is to ensure that systems are more safe by default.
fields.summary: brute force password attack protection by default

fields.description: If a group name has a XSS shaped name, then the group picker will allow scripts to be executed.
fields.summary: Group picker popup JSP has XSS hole if group names are XSS shaped
Brute force protection on JIRA 4.1 leaks valid account names

fields.description:
The current CAPTCHA implementation displays a different message if the CAPTCHA is being displayed and the captcha is entered correctly but the password for the user is not, than if the CAPTCHA is entered incorrectly. This is giving away more information than a login screen should. The error message that is displayed whilst a captcha is being displayed should remain constant.

eg. "Sorry, your username, password or captcha is incorrect - please try again."
fields.summary: The current CAPTCHA implementation may not be secure

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21034].
  {panel}

The current CAPTCHA system in JIRA is both very hard to decipher for end users, and not accessible.

It would be good if there was, as a minimum, an option to generate a new image on the fly without having to reload the page. That would improve usability but not solve the accessibility issues though.

It would be great if one could, for example through a plugin, swap the default CAPTCHA provider with another one. This could solve both readability and accessibility issues. The Recaptcha project at http://recaptcha.net/ — which was unfortunately dismissed without consideration in CONF-9026 — is an excellent candidate.

Note that this improvement request is valid for other Atlassian products (e.g. CROWD, CONFLUENCE...)
fields.summary: Allow for different CAPTCHA providers

fields.description:
Build a new gadget that would be added to one's dashboard that would show all issues that have been updated in some way that they "typically" would have been notified on via email (reporter, watcher - assignee would be optional).

Instead of sending an email (or as an option, one could choose to only send notifications, only load into this gadget, or do both).  As the user reviews the change to an issue, they would check off that they are done with it, and it would fall off the gadget and no longer be displayed.

I am desperately trying to reduce our reliance on email, and although email notifications are great for some things, it would be far better if most of this information was just contained in the JIRA tool itself, and one could go to the dashboard, review this gadget for a list of all issues that had some change to it that have yet to be reviewed, and then check it off in the gadget since you have now reviewed it.  This would allow a dramatic reduction in emails being sent.

Perhaps additional functionality would be an option to have a digest sent from this gadget on some period - say daily or weekly - to remind the person to go to review this gadget, but this would be 1 email a day or week as opposed to the at least ~70+ that I get now each week due to people updating an issue in some way that I either reported or that I am a watcher on (I am in a leadership role, so I am tied to a bunch of issues in our system).

I believe the ability to send out an instant email notification for someone who was just assigned an issue should still be allowed, but perhaps optionally.  I personally would leave this set to instant when I am assigned to an issue, and I would ask my team to do the same, but some users might want this to be an option.

I know there is a "to do" list macro for Confluence that is similar to this request.  The difference is that this would be dynamically built by the JIRA gadget, and it would have to retain (persistent) all changes that you have not reviewed since the time the gadget was added to the dashboard.  Once the item was checked, it would be permanently removed from the gadget and no longer display (just like when I delete my notification email out of my inbox never to look at it again), but obviously all historical data is still retained in JIRA.
fields.summary: Dashboard Checklist Gadget of Changes to Items I Reported or am Watching
